sub_topic: Calculating the effect of changing the concentration of a salt on the solubility of a sparingly soluble salt
message_1: What is the final concentration of silver ions (Ag+) in a saturated solution of silver chloride (AgCl) when the concentration of chloride ions (Cl-) is increased from 0.1 M to 0.2 M? The Ksp of AgCl is 1.8 x 10^-10.
message_2:
To find the final concentration of silver ions (Ag+) in a saturated solution of silver chloride (AgCl) when the concentration of chloride ions (Cl-) is increased from 0.1 M to 0.2 M, we can use the solubility product constant (Ksp) expression for AgCl:

Ksp = [Ag+][Cl-]

Given that the Ksp of AgCl is 1.8 x 10^-10, we can set up the equation as follows:

1.8 x 10^-10 = [Ag+][0.2]

Now, we can solve for the concentration of silver ions (Ag+):

[Ag+] = (1.8 x 10^-10) / 0.2
[Ag+] = 9 x 10^-10 M

So, the final concentration of silver ions (Ag+) in the saturated solution of silver chloride (AgCl) when the concentration of chloride ions (Cl-) is increased from 0.1 M to 0.2 M is 9 x 10^-10 M.
